lines.text:
[arriving at stakeout location, carrying cases of equipment]
Hey Barn! I got everything we need! I got 10-guage shotguns, 12-guage shotguns, tow phone, and
[opens largest case]
tear gas!
Did you bring a chair?
Chair?

[gestures to empty apartment]
There's no place to sit down.
Ooh, sorry.

[looks into equipment case]
I see you brought grenades too, huh?
Just a thought.
If we don't use all this stuff, you're not going to feel bad, are you?

[hangs head]
No.

[to Harris, who is stoned on hashish brownies]
I want you to go home until you feel better.

[grinning]
Hey, I'll go home... but I ain't never gonna feel better!
And I don't want you driving a car; take the bus.
Okay... wait. If I can't drive a car...
[laughing]
I better not try to drive a BUS!
That's not the way we operate around here. We do everything by the book, according to regulations, above board.
I believe you.
You don't look like you do.
It's my face. I mean this face doesn't look like it trusts anybody. When I proposed to my wife, she thought I was joking. This face is a curse.
I've always admired the Japanese outlook on death. The calm acceptance, the treating it as a part of life...

[to Wojo]
I dunno what he's talking about - personally, I'm going kicking and screaming all the way.
Well, why don't you tell him that?
I like my image.
My old man took me to ball game once when I was a kid. I think we saw the Mets and the Cubs.
Oh yeah, that's always a good game.
He got me a little pennant, a hot dog and a beer. We had really great seats.
Sounds like your dad was a nice guy.
He was a mugger. Some guy he rolled had season tickets. Halfway through the game, a cop showed up. Dragged us both out of there.
Oh.
Wanna hear about the puppy I got for Christmas?

[eating Chinese take out with pencils]
Just call your insurance company. Yes. Don't mention it.
[hangs up phone]
Oh my God. I ate my eraser.

[discovering that the squadroom has been vandalized, Barney reads graffiti spray-painted in the hallway]
"Captain Miller is a dirty m... " Ha, ha, ha, marvelous.
Hey, Barney, do you think Kelly's just a big mouth? Or, is he really going to try to make trouble?
I think Kelly is just a big mouth... who's really going to try to make trouble.
He's probably after me. Kelly's always had a thing about Orientals being on the police force. He says we screw up the look of the Saint Patrick's Day Parade.

[brings Mayflower, who's dressed in full pimp regalia into the Squad Room]
Okay. Come on. Come on. Come on.
Hey, man, since when is it a crime to come to the defense of a lady and try and protect her honor? Since *when*?
When you push her trick out of a second story window.
Don't tell *me* chivalry ain't dead!
So What do you do for fun? Watch TV?
It's not in the bible.
Movies?
Not in the Bible.
Play cards? Gamble?
It's not in the Bible.
What DO you DO for fun?
Got 14 kids. THAT'S in the Bible.
Then Fish runs in the alley and he leaps over us like one of those, what do you call those things in Africa that run and leap in the air?
Slaves.
Was that Mrs. Miller?
Yeah.
Past tense was unintentional.

[Fish is depressed over his age]
When Wilson and I were chasing that kid... Do you know what it feels like to be running down 43rd Street, and your partner is cornering a guy on 52nd? Do you how I found out what happened? I asked a reporter! *Four* radio stations beat me to the scene of the crime!

[while getting ready for a stakeout]
Fish, we're going to have to draw special weapons.

[Extremely excited about being allowed to go on his first stakeout]
Hey, let me do it! I'll go down to the armoury. Let's see, what do we need? Shotguns! Tear gas! Gas masks!
[He leaves the squadroom to go draw the weapons]

[Observing Wojo's enthusiam about the weapons]
Nice boy.
It takes so little to make him happy.
So Dietrich, big plans for the weekend?
No, I'm staying home. I've gotten involved in the New Celibacy Movement.
Oh, Yeah?. what's that?
Its a movement for people who are fed up with the whole shallow dating scene.
Couldn't get a date, huh?
Not a single one.
[Nick is talking to Internal Affairs]
I'm not Chinese, you know.
That doesn't matter, Detective.
Now it doesn't matter; but in 1942...

[Fish runs back into the squad room]
Hey, where is everybody?
Wilson, get out of here! There's a bomb in the building!

[locked in the cage]
Oh, Mother in heaven!
Goodbye, Marty.
Arnold, don't you dare leave me here!

[indicates Marty]
Wilson, get him out of here!
If you ever catch the lunatic who did this
[hands Wilson his business card]
tell him to call me.
[runs out]
Hurry and open this door.

[frantically searches]
I'm looking for the key.
Nobody's answering the phone! I've got to cover the rest of the building!
Go ahead! Hey... I got your case back!
What case?
Your briefcase, on the desk!
Thanks!
[runs out again]
Aren't those the keys on the desk?
[Wilson runs to get them]

[slides back into the squad room and stares at the briefcase]
Wilson... I don't own a briefcase.

[stares at briefcase as it dawns on him]
It ain't yours?
No.
Who cares whose case it is? Just get the door open!
Wilson... the bomb is in the briefcase.
Holy Mama!
Oh, my God! Is it a big bomb?
How the hell do I know?

[looks at watch]
It's two minutes to five!
Fish, we've got to get rid of it!

[after Chano and Fish return from a bank robbery and Chano is acting very strangely]
What happened?

Two armed men. One with a shotgun. One with a handgun. Shot a guard. Held six people hostage and threatened to kill them if we didn't let them go. It'd have gone on all day if *someone* didn't get inside.
Apparently someone did.
Chano... killed both of them.

[comes into the Squad Room dressed in a patrolman's uniform]
Patrolman Kelly reporting for duty.
For an undercover cop, that's a pretty dumb disguise.
Mine's the sashimi and cream cheese on a bagel.
You mean lox?
We had it first.

[when he's stoned on the brownies with the hashish]
Barney, Barney, Barney, is your mother from Killarney?
[a minute later]
What do you say we guys go down to the beach, and shoot some clams?
Barney, divorce is like a horse with a broken leg. You can shoot the horse, but that don't fix the leg.
Barney, his wife has decided not to press charges, so I let him go after giving him that spiel you always give about "not losing one's perspective."
I'm... flattered that you chose to use it.
Well, I thought it oughta be in the public domain *by now*...
Hey Fish, does it hurt when those stones come out?
It can't be too bad. The doctor says it's like giving birth.
What happened Levitt?
I talked it over with a couple of doctors and they said 'forget it'.
Incurable, hunh?
Yes sir. Five six and a half, that's it.
The doctor said he was very lucky, the bullet just grazed him.
Where'd she hit him?
In the inseam.
[a man and a woman have to share the holding cell]
Did you kill your wife?

[whispering]
Yes, but they don't know about that, yet.
Take Officer LEVITT with you.
Hunh? Okay. Let's go Levine.
[Levitt rolls his eys and joins him]
Arrest the first naked guy you see with a dirty mouth.
If you want real police brutaity, wait until I tell you what they served me for lunch.
Hey mother, you're not gonna leave me here, are you?
I'm not your mother.
You sure you ain't got a son?
I'm sure.
You wanna buy one? Don't leave me, mother!
[Bernice exits]
That mother left me.

Plaza AcadÈ, the Bristol and the Creon. The villa in the South of France costs $1,250 a week. Then we fly back to Paris and then back to New York. That makes the whole thing cost $26,000 for six weeks. Can we afford it?
No.
Okay.
[tosses brochure in the garbage]
How about taking me to lunch?
You didn't have to go through all that just to get me to take you to lunch.
I thought you would be more excited about the idea if you thought I saved you $26,000.

[searching the files for a bombing suspect]
Who else you got?

[looks at file folder]
Sheldon "Boom-Boom" Hockster.
"Boom-Boom"?
You'd be amazed at how many of these guys are named "Boom-Boom".

[sees Fish limping]
What's the matter with your foot?
Gout.
Rich cooking, huh?
No. *Poor* cooking, but rich food.

[answers phone]
12th Precinct Detective, Sergeant Amanguale speaking. No, ma'am, I'm sorry but we can't trace them. There's very little we can do about obscene phone calls. No, ma'am. No, ma'am. Will you watch your language, please, ma'am?
[hangs up phone]
This is gonna drive me crazy. 26 calls in two weeks!
[thinks about it]
That's some dirty guy.

[walks tiredly into the Squad Room]
Good morning.

[looks at watch]
You're late.
I interviewed a *lot* of women last night that got dirty phone calls. I had to take down *all* of the conversations. I got names. I got addresses. I also got excited.
[indicates notepads]
Do you want me to type up these reports?
Maybe you'd better let Fish do it.
Good.You know, these guys that make dirty phone calls gotta be very lonely people. They spend so much time talking on the telephone they never get to meet anybody.
I wish he'd start writing dirty letters. Then the Post Office could worry about it.
Hey, Fish. Who's Esther Williams?
She covered herself with grease and swam the English Channel.
[to himself]
It's a shame Bernice can't swim she'd be all set.
